title: Erdős Problem #950: Sum of Reciprocal Prime Gaps
description: Study the behavior of f(n) = ∑_{p<n} 1/(n-p), the sum of reciprocals of distances to primes.

overview.historicalContext: This problem concerns the function f(n) = ∑_{p<n} 1/(n-p), which measures how 'close' n is to primes by weighting nearby primes more heavily. De Bruijn, Erdős, and Turán showed that ∑_{n<x} f(n) ~ x and ∑_{n<x} f(n)² ~ x, meaning f(n) averages to 1.
overview.problemStatement: Define f(n) = ∑_{p<n} 1/(n-p) where p ranges over primes. Three questions: (1) Is lim inf f(n) = 1? (2) Is lim sup f(n) = ∞? (3) Is f(n) = o(log log n) for all n?
overview.proofStrategy: The known average results suggest f(n) fluctuates around 1. Question 1 asks if f(n) can get arbitrarily close to 1 from below. Question 2 asks if f(n) can be arbitrarily large. Question 3 asks for a universal upper bound.
keyInsights: f(n) weights nearby primes more heavily via 1/(n-p)
f(n) is large when n has many nearby primes
f(n) is small when n is in a 'prime desert'
The three questions probe different aspects of the distribution

sections.title: The Function f(n)
sections.content: f(n) = ∑_{p<n} 1/(n-p) sums the reciprocals of distances from n to all primes less than n. A prime p close to n contributes a large term 1/(n-p), while distant primes contribute little.

sections.title: Three Questions
sections.content: Q1: Is lim inf f(n) = 1? This asks if f(n) can approach 1 from above infinitely often. Q2: Is lim sup f(n) = ∞? This asks if f(n) is unbounded. Q3: Is f(n) = o(log log n)? This asks for a slow-growing upper bound.

sections.title: Known Results
sections.content: De Bruijn, Erdős, and Turán proved ∑_{n<x} f(n) ~ x and ∑_{n<x} f(n)² ~ x. This means the average value of f(n) is 1, and f(n)² also averages to 1, indicating f(n) concentrates near 1 on average.

sections.title: Weaker Conjecture
sections.content: Erdős proposed: for every ε > 0, large x has some y < x with π(x) < π(y) + ε·π(x-y). If a stronger bound holds (with O((x-y)/log x)), then f(n) ≪ log log log n.

sections.title: Connection to Prime Distribution
sections.content: f(n) reflects the local distribution of primes near n. Regions dense in primes give large f(n); prime deserts give small f(n). The questions probe the extremal behavior of this distribution.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #950 asks three questions about f(n) = ∑_{p<n} 1/(n-p): Is lim inf = 1? Is lim sup = ∞? Is f(n) = o(log log n)? The average is known to be 1, but extremal behavior is open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would illuminate the fine structure of prime distribution. Answering Q1 and Q2 would characterize fluctuations of f(n) around its mean. Q3 would provide a universal bound.
openQuestions: What is the true growth rate of max_{n ≤ x} f(n)?
Can we characterize n where f(n) is extremal?
